content.text: The Bamboo Cutter: The Tale of the Moon Princess  Long, long ago, in the quiet and misty mountains of Japan, there lived an old bamboo cutter named Taketori no Okina.
He was a kind and gentle man, known far and wide for his skill in crafting beautiful things from bamboo.
Every morning, he would venture into the bamboo grove, his hands rough but careful as he selected the finest stalks to carve into baskets, lanterns, and delicate ornaments.
One evening, as the sun dipped below the hills and painted the sky in shades of pink and gold, the old man made his way home through the whispering bamboo.
Suddenly, a soft golden light caught his eye.
It glowed from within one of the tallest stalks, shimmering like a tiny star trapped in the green.
Curious, he reached out and gently split the bamboo open.
Inside, nestled among the pale fibers, sat the tiniest, most perfect little girl he had ever seen.
She was no bigger than his thumb, her skin as fair as moonlight, her eyes like dark pools of ink.
The old man gasped in wonder. "Oh!" he cried.
"Who are you, little one?"  The child said nothing, but she smiled up at him with such sweetness that his heart melted.
Carefully, he lifted her from the bamboo and cradled her in his palm.
"I shall take you home," he said, "and raise you as my own."  And so, the old bamboo cutter carried the child to his humble cottage, where his wife, a warm and loving woman, waited.
When she saw the tiny girl, her eyes filled with tears of joy.
"She is a gift from the gods!" she exclaimed.
Together, they decided to name her Kaguya-hime, which means "Princess of the Radiant Night," for she had appeared like a blessing from the heavens.
From that day on, strange and wonderful things began to happen.
Every time the old man cut bamboo, he found nuggets of gold hidden inside the stalks.
Soon, he and his wife grew rich, though they remained as kind and humble as ever. And Kaguya-hime?
Oh, she grew more beautiful with each passing day.
Her hair was as black as a raven’s wing, her voice like the song of a nightingale, and her presence filled their home with light.
Word of the miraculous child spread far and wide.
People came from distant villages just to catch a glimpse of her, and soon, noblemen and princes began to visit, hoping to win her hand in marriage.
Five of the bravest and wealthiest men in the land arrived at the old couple’s door, each declaring their love for Kaguya-hime.
But the princess was wise and gentle, and she did not wish to marry.
Still, she did not want to hurt their feelings. So, she devised a plan.
"I will marry the one who can bring me a treasure I desire," she said.
"But know this—these treasures are not ordinary.

They are rare and nearly impossible to find."  To the first prince, she said, "Bring me the stone begging bowl of the Buddha from India." To the second, "Fetch me a jeweled branch from the mythical island of Horai." To the third, "I wish for the robe made of the fire-rat’s fur." To the fourth, "Find me a dragon’s five-colored jewel." And to the fifth, "Bring me the cowrie shell that was born from a swallow’s nest."  The princes set off at once, eager to prove their love.
But oh, what foolish and desperate things they did!
The first prince, too lazy to travel to India, bought an ordinary bowl and painted it black, pretending it was the Buddha’s.
When he presented it to Kaguya-hime, she examined it closely and said, "This is not the true bowl.
I can see the paint flaking." The prince’s face turned red with shame, and he fled in disgrace.
The second prince, who had been tasked with finding the jeweled branch, hired craftsmen to create a fake one.
It was beautiful, covered in gold and glittering gems.
But when Kaguya-hime touched it, she said, "This branch was made by human hands.
The true branch from Horai would never tarnish." The craftsmen, who had been hiding nearby, stepped forward and demanded payment.
The prince, caught in his lie, ran away in humiliation.
The third prince, who sought the fire-rat’s robe, traveled to China and bought what he thought was the magical fur.
But when Kaguya-hime held it to a flame, it burned to ashes.
"This is not the robe of the fire-rat," she said sadly.
"The true robe would never burn." The prince, realizing he had been tricked by the merchant, hung his head in defeat.
The fourth prince, who had been sent to find the dragon’s jewel, set sail on a stormy sea.
But when a great dragon appeared before him, he was so frightened that he forgot to ask for the jewel.
Instead, he begged for his life and returned empty-handed. Kaguya-hime sighed. "You did not even try," she said.
"How can I marry a man who fears dragons?"  The fifth prince, who had been tasked with finding the swallow’s cowrie shell, climbed to the highest rafters of a temple to search for a swallow’s nest.
But in his haste, he lost his footing and fell, breaking his arm. He, too, returned with nothing.
The old bamboo cutter and his wife were heartbroken.
They had hoped that one of the princes would succeed, for they wished to see Kaguya-hime happy.
But the princess remained gentle and kind, though she refused to marry any of them.
Then, one day, the Emperor of Japan himself heard of Kaguya-hime’s beauty.
He traveled to the bamboo cutter’s home and gazed upon her with awe.
"Surely," he said, "no woman in the world is as lovely as you.
Will you be my bride?"  Kaguya-hime bowed her head. "Your Majesty," she said softly, "I am deeply honored.
But I cannot marry you, for I am not of this world."  The Emperor was puzzled.
"What do you mean?" he asked. Kaguya-hime sighed. "I come from the Moon," she explained.
"Long ago, I was sent to Earth as a punishment for a small mistake.
But now, my time here is coming to an end.
On the next full moon, my people will come to take me home."  The Emperor’s heart sank.
"No!" he cried. "I will not let them take you!
I will protect you with my armies!"  But Kaguya-hime shook her head.
"No army can stop the Moon People," she said.
"And though I have grown to love this life, I must return."  As the days passed, Kaguya-hime grew sadder.
She spent her time weaving a robe of feathers, for she knew she would need it to return to the Moon.
The old bamboo cutter and his wife wept, and even the Emperor could not bear to see her so sorrowful.
On the night of the full moon, the sky filled with a soft, silver light.
The Emperor’s soldiers surrounded the bamboo cutter’s home, their swords drawn.
But as the clock struck midnight, a great procession descended from the heavens.
Celestial beings in robes of light floated down, their faces kind but unyielding.
Kaguya-hime stepped forward, her eyes filled with tears.
"Father, Mother," she said to the old couple, "I will never forget your love.
And Your Majesty," she said to the Emperor, "I will always remember your kindness."  She handed the Emperor a letter and a small vial of the Elixir of Life.
"If you truly love me," she said, "burn this letter and the elixir on the highest mountain in Japan.
Then, my memory will live on in the smoke that rises to the heavens."  With that, she placed the robe of feathers over her shoulders and rose into the air.
The Moon People surrounded her, and together, they ascended into the night sky, leaving the Earth behind.
The old bamboo cutter and his wife wept bitterly, and the Emperor, heartbroken, ordered his men to take the letter and the elixir to the top of Mount Fuji.
There, they burned them, and the smoke rose high into the sky, carrying Kaguya-hime’s memory with it.
And so, the people of Japan say that on clear nights, when the moon is full, you can still see the faintest glow of Kaguya-hime’s light shining down upon the Earth.
And if you listen very carefully, you might just hear the whisper of her voice on the wind, telling you that love, though sometimes painful, is the most precious treasure of all.
